questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the framework of the external nose?

choices.text: Upper ½ is bony and lower ½ is cartilaginous
Upper 2/3rd is bony and lower 1/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.solution: Upper 1/3rd of the external nose is bony, whereas lower 2/3rd is cartilaginous.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the cartilaginous part of the external nose?
questions.solution:
The external nose is made up of 3 paired and 1 unpaired cartilages.

Paired cartilages:

  • Upper lateral cartilage - From nasal bone above to alar cartilage below.
  • Lower lateral (alar) cartilage - U-shaped.  Lateral crus forms the ala and medial crus runs in the columella. Limen nasi or limen vestibuli is the junction of the upper and lower lateral cartilages.
  • Lesser alar (sesamoid) cartilage - multiple, above, and lateral to the alar cartilage.

The septal cartilage is the only unpaired cartilage. It forms the midline of the lower 2/3rd of the dorsum of nose and supports lower 2/3rd of the dorsum of external nose.

questions.text: What is the shape of the septal cartilage?
questions.solution:
Septal cartilage is a quadrilateral cartilage.

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: A boxer suffered a blow to the nose. You suspect a fracture of his external nasal bones. Which of the following will you not expect to contribute to the fracture?
questions.solution:
Sphenoid bone does not contribute to the bony part of the external nose.

The bony part of the external nose consists of

  • Two nasal bones
  • Frontal process of maxilla lateral to nasal bones on each side.
  • Nasal process of frontal bone in the midline between 2 nasal bones.
  • Nasion is the site of the junction of nasal bone with the nasal process of the frontal bone.

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

Septum proper is an osseocartilaginous framework made up of:

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not contribute to the formation of the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Perpendicular plate of sphenoid does not contribute to the formation of the nasal septum.

Related Pearl: Nasal Septum

  • Septal or quadrilateral cartilage
  • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid
  • Vomer
  • Others – crest of nasal bones, nasal spine of frontal bone, rostrum of sphenoid, crest of palatine bones and the crest maxilla, and the anterior nasal spine of maxilla

questions.text: What are the choanae also known as?
questions.solution:
The choanae are also known as posterior nares.

Each nasal cavity communicates with the exterior through the anterior nares or nostril and with the nasopharynx through the posterior nares, posterior nasal aperture or the choanae.

Limen nasi or the nasal valve is the upper limit of nasal vestibule on the lateral wall. It demarcates the skin-lined vestibule with the mucosa-lined nasal cavity proper.

Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinate.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal congestion and the following test is performed. Which of the following does not contribute to the boundaries of the involved structure?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Cottle's test being performed and the structure involved is the nasal valve. 

Middle turbinate does not contribute to the boundaries of the nasal valve.

In Cottle's test, the cheek of the patient is drawn laterally during quiet breathing. If this improves the airway on the test side, the test is considered to be positive. This suggests an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve causing nasal obstruction.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of the nasal valve

  • Laterally: Lower border of upper lateral cartilage and fibrofatty tissue and anterior end of inferior turbinate
  • Medially: Cartilaginous nasal septum
  • Caudally: Floor of the pyriform aperture

The nasal valve is the narrowest part and offers maximum resistance to airflow

questions.text: Given below is the endoscopic view of the right nasal cavity. Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the lowermost projection in the lateral wall of the nose, the inferior turbinate. The middle turbinate (Option B) is seen as superior to it.

The lateral wall of the nose contains three or sometimes four projections of variable size namely superior, middle, and inferior turbinates along with a corresponding meatus under each turbinate.

The inferior turbinate is the largest turbinate and occupies the lower third of the lateral nasal wall. It is a separate bone. Middle and superior turbinates (Option C) are ethmoturbinal, part of the ethmoid bone.

Other important structures which could be seen in the above image are:

  • IT: Inferior turbinate
  • S: Septum,
  • MT: middle turbinate

Uncinate process (Option D) is a hook-like structure running parallel to the anterior border of bulla ethmoidalis. The posteroinferior end of the uncinate process is attached to the inferior turbinate. 

The image below shows a CT image of the uncinate process.

questions.text: Which of the following articulates with the maxilla?
questions.solution:
The inferior turbinate articulates with the nasal surface of the maxilla and the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone. 

The superior, middle, and supreme turbinates are present in the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone.

The image given below shows the nasal cavity, inferior turbinate and opening of maxillary sinus.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman was admitted with complaints of longstanding breathing difficulties and headaches. On evaluation, a deviated nasal septum was noted. CT image is given below. Which of the following structures is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and CT findings are suggestive of concha bullosa. It is the pneumatization of the middle turbinate and is one of the anatomic variations of the paranasal region.

Concha bullosa can be either unilateral or bilateral and generally occurs together with a septal deviation to the contralateral side.

In the image given below, the star-marked area is the enlarged, ballooned out middle turbinate called concha bullosa.

questions.text: In a patient with refractory posterior epistaxis, a transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation is planned. During the operation, the surgeon asks you to clip the artery at the sphenopalatine foramen. Where will you locate the site of ligation?
questions.solution:
Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is done to control refractory posterior epistaxis by ligating the sphenopalatine artery. It emerges from the sphenopalatine foramen which is situated at the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

Branches of sphenopalatine ganglion also emerge from the sphenopalatine foramen. It supplies most of the posterior 2/3rd of the nasal cavity. It can be anaesthetized by placing a pledget of cotton soaked in anaesthetic solution at the foramen.

The sphenopalatine foramen is also the most common site for the origin of angiofibroma.

Hiatus semilunaris is present in the middle meatus. It is a two-dimensional space bounded by bulla ethmoidalis above and uncinate process below.

It opens into a three-dimensional area called infundibulum bounded by uncinate process, frontal process of maxilla medially, and lamina papyracea laterally. The maxillary sinus opens into lower part of infundibulum.

The image given below shows the opening of maxillary sinus

questions.text: Which of the following sinuses does not open into the middle meatus?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal sinus does not open into the middle meatus. It opens into the superior meatus.

Frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses open into middle meatus.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Where is the ethmoidal bulla present?
questions.solution:
Ethmoidal bulla (Bulla ethmoidalis) is an ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process.

It forms the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child presents with congenital dacryocystitis and requires probing of the nasolacrimal duct to relieve the obstruction. Where will the probe emerge in the nasal cavity?
questions.solution:
The probe emerges in the inferior meatus because the opening of the nasolacrimal duct is present in the inferior meatus. 

The nasolacrimal duct runs downwards, backward, and laterally from the lacrimal sac and opens into the inferior meatus.

It is bounded by a mucosal valve called the valve of Hasner in the inferior meatus.

Note: In congenital dacryocystitis, probing of the nasolacrimal duct is done at 9-12 months of age if symptoms persist past 6 months of age and aren't relieved by local massage and topical antibiotics. 

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: While performing diagnostic nasal endoscopy, which of the following structures would you not see during the third pass?
questions.solution:
The third pass in diagnostic nasal endoscopy involves the examination of the middle meatus in detail. The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus, hence it will not be visualized here. 

Option A: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate. When pneumatised and enlarged it encroaches on the frontal recess area and causes mechanical obstruction to drainage of the frontal sinus leading to sinusitis.

Option B: Atrium of the middle meatus is a shallow depression lying in front of the middle turbinate and above the nasal vestibule.

Option C: Fronto-nasal duct/frontal recess is the opening of the frontal sinus into the infundibulum.

Note: In diagnostic nasal endoscopy three passes are performed -

  1. First pass is the examination of the nasopharynx and inferior meatus.
  2. Second pass is the examination of sphenoethmoidal recess, superior meatus, and openings of sphenoid sinus and posterior ethmoidal cells.
  3. Third pass is the examination of the middle meatus in detail.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the olfactory area of the nose?

choices.text: The olfactory area is known as the dangerous area of the nose
Bounded laterally by superior turbinate, medially by corresponding part of septum, above by cribriform plate of ethmoid bone
Trauma can lead to spread of infection intracranially and can cause CSF rhinorrhea
The olfactory area is very well ventilated and it aids in olfaction

questions.solution:
The olfactory area is not well ventilated, and very little air passes through the olfactory region during quiet inspiration. Weak odors need to be sniffed, due to the same.

The upper 1/3rd of the nasal cavity forms the olfactory area which is also known as the dangerous area of the nose. Olfactory nerve fibers pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid. Spread of infection to the intracranial space can occur through this route. Trauma to the cribriform plate can lead to CSF rhinorrhea. 

It is bounded by the following structures:

  • Laterally by superior turbinate
  • Medially by corresponding part of the septum
  • Superiorly by cribriform plate of the ethmoid

It is lined by olfactory epithelium.

Note: The danger triangle of the face consists of the area from the corners of the mouth to the bridge of the nose. This is because retrograde infection from these areas can spread to the brain, through the venous communication (via the ophthalmic veins) between the facial vein and the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented with nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea refractory to medical treatment. On examination, turbinates were hypertrophied. She was scheduled for vidian neurectomy. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the nerve supply of the region?

choices.text: Parasympathetic supply is from greater superficial petrosal nerve
Sympathetic supply is by upper two thoracic segments of spinal cord
Parasympathetic stimulation causes vasodilatation and sympathetic stimulation causes vasoconstriction
Sympathetic fibres of the nerve of pterygoid canal relay in the sphenopalatine ganglion

questions.solution:
The given case scenario with rhinorrhea, nasal obstruction, and turbinate hypertrophy is suggestive of vasomotor rhinitis (VMR). Vidian neurectomy is the treatment of choice in VMR refractory to medical treatment. The autonomic nerve supply of the nose is unstable in cases of VMR. Sympathetic fibres of the nerve of the pterygoid canal do not relay in the sphenopalatine ganglion.
 
  Parasympathetic supply Sympathetic supply
Nerve fibres arise from  Greater superficial petrosal nerve Upper two thoracic segments of spinal cord
Course

Travel in the nerve of pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve) to the sphenopalatine ganglion

Superior cervical ganglion to deep petrosal nerve to parasympathetic fibres of greater petrosal nerve - nerve of pterygoid canal
Relay

Relays in the sphenopalatine ganglion before reaching nasal cavity

Doesn't relay in sphenopalatine ganglion
Function

Vasodilation

Vasoconstriction

questions.text: At what site does the maxillary sinus open into the middle meatus?
questions.solution:
Maxillary sinus opens into middle meatus at the lower part of infundibulum, in its medial wall.

Infundibulum is the space limited medially by the uncinate process and frontal process of maxilla, and laterally by the lamina papyracea.
